briefdescription.para: Checks if a scalar is NaN.

detaileddescription.para:
x
scalar to be checked
true if x is NaN, false otherwise
Checks if value x is NaN (not a number). This is done by checking if x is unequal to itself, which is only true for NaN values.

memberdef.argsstring: (double x, double x0, double x1, double y0, double y1)
memberdef.name: linearInterpolation

briefdescription.para: Performs linear interpolation.

detaileddescription.para:
x
Point at which to interpolate
x0
First known point
x1
Second known point
y0
Value at first known point
y1
Value at second known point
Interpolated value at point x
Performs linear interpolation to find the value at point x given two known points (x0, y0) and (x1, y1). If x is outside the range [x0, x1], the function will perform linear extrapolation.

briefdescription.para: Computes the exponential of value x with numerical limits check.

detaileddescription.para:
x
Exponent to which e is raised
exponential of x
If x is larger than the maximum limit of double precision floating point numbers, the maximum limit is returned. If x is smaller than the minimum limit, the minimum limit is returned.

briefdescription.para: Runtime factorial.
Extracts the exponent to the power of ten from a floating point number.

detaileddescription.para:
x
Input floating point number
Exponent to the power of ten
This function extracts the exponent to the power of ten from a given floating point number. For example, for an input of 3e5, the function will return 5. If the input number is very close to zero (between -1e-16 and 1e-16), the function returns 0.

briefdescription.para: Convert angle from radiant to degree.

detaileddescription.para:
alpha
Angle in radiant
Angle in degree
Converts angle alpha given in radiant to degree.

briefdescription.para: Convert angle from degree to radiant.

detaileddescription.para:
alpha
Angle in degree
Angle in radiant
Converts angle alpha given in degree to radiant.

briefdescription.para: Macaulay function applied to a scalar.

detaileddescription.para:
scalar
Input value
Positive part of scalar
The Macaulay function, also as positive part operator, is defined as: \[\langle x \rangle = \begin{cases} x, & x \geq 0 \\ 0, & x < 0 \end{cases} \]

briefdescription.para: Heaviside step function applied to a scalar.

detaileddescription.para:
scalar
Input value
1 if scalar >= 0, 0 otherwise
The Heaviside step function is defined as: \[H(x) = \begin{cases} 1, & x \geq 0 \\ 0, & x < 0 \end{cases} \]

briefdescription.para: Heaviside step function excluding zero applied to a scalar.

detaileddescription.para:
scalar
Input value
1 if scalar > 0, 0 otherwise
The Heaviside step function excluding zero is defined as: \[H(x) = \begin{cases} 1, & x > 0 \\ 0, & x \leq 0 \end{cases} \]

briefdescription.para: Sign function applied to a scalar.

detaileddescription.para:
val
Input value
1 if val > 0, -1 if val < 0, 0 if val == 0
The sign function is defined as: \[ \text{sign}(x) = \begin{cases} 1, & x > 0 \\ 0, & x = 0 \\ -1, & x < 0 \end{cases} \]

briefdescription.para: Converts various scalar types to double precision floating point numbers.

detaileddescription.para:
value
Input value of various numeric types
Converted value as double
This function converts input values of different numeric types, including:
double
std::complex<double>
autodiff::real
autodiff::dual
Eigen::Matrix with elements of any type convertible to double
The function is overloaded and templated to handle these different types appropriately.

briefdescription.para: Converts autodiff::dual numbers to double precision floating point numbers.

detaileddescription.para:
T
Underlying type of the autodiff::dual number
G
Gradient type of the autodiff::dual number
number
Input autodiff::dual number
Converted value as double
This function converts an autodiff::dual number to a double precision floating point number. It is templated to handle dual numbers with different underlying types.

briefdescription.para: Extracts the real part of a arbitrary scalartype-valued Matrix.

parameterdescription.para: parameter pack for additional matrix information, e.g, dimensions

briefdescription.para: Extracts the real part of a arbitrary scalartype-valued Vector.
Apply Macaulay function to a matrix.

detaileddescription.para:
nRows
Number of rows in the matrix
nCols
Number of columns in the matrix
mat
Input matrix
Matrix with Macaulay function applied element-wise
Applies the Macaulay function element-wise to the input matrix.

xrefdescription.para: : Can be replaced easily with Eigen's array() functionality ???

memberdef.argsstring: (yType yN, const double dt, functionType fRate, Args &&... fRateArgs)
memberdef.name: explicitEuler

briefdescription.para: Explicit Euler time integrator.

detaileddescription.para:
yN
Current value
dt
Time step size
fRate
Function that computes the rate of change
fRateArgs
Additional arguments for the rate function
Updated value after time step
This function computes one single time step using the explicit Euler method: \[ \boldsymbol{y}_{n+1} = \boldsymbol{y}_n + f(\boldsymbol{y}_n) * \Delta t \] where $ \boldsymbol{y}_n $ is the current value, $ \Delta t $ is the time step size, and $ f(\boldsymbol{y}_n) $ is the rate of change.

memberdef.argsstring: (Eigen::Matrix< double, ySize, 1 > yN, const double dt, functionType fRate, Args &&... fRateArgs)
memberdef.name: semiImplicitEuler

briefdescription.para: Implicit Euler time integrator for a linear vector-valued rate equation.

detaileddescription.para:
yN
Current value
dt
Time step size
fRate
Function that computes the rate of change
fRateArgs
Additional arguments for the rate function
Updated value after time step
This function computes one single time step using the implicit Euler method for a linear vector-valued rate equation: \[ \boldsymbol{y}_{n+1} = \boldsymbol{y}_n + f(\boldsymbol{y}_{n+1}) \Delta t \] where $\boldsymbol{y}_n $ is the current value, $ \Delta t $ is the time step size, and $ f(\boldsymbol{y}) $ is the linear rate of change evaluated at the next time step.

xrefdescription.para: : Is this really semi-implicit? It looks like a fully implicit Euler step for linear systems.

memberdef.argsstring: (yType yN, const double dt, functionType fRate, Args &&... fRateArgs)
memberdef.name: explicitEulerRichardson

briefdescription.para: Explicit Euler integration with error estimation based on Richardson extrapolation.

detaileddescription.para:
functionType
Type of the rate function
yType
Type of the current value
Args
Additional argument types for the rate function
yN
Current value
dt
Time step size
fRate
Function that computes the rate of change
fRateArgs
Additional arguments for the rate function
Updated value after time step
This function computes one single time step using the explicit Euler method with Richardson extrapolation for error estimation: \[ \boldsymbol{y}_{n+1} = 2 \left( \boldsymbol{y}_n + f\left(\boldsymbol{y}_n + \frac{f(\boldsymbol{y}_n) \Delta t}{2}\right) \frac{\Delta t}{2} \right) - \left( \boldsymbol{y}_n + f(\boldsymbol{y}_n) \Delta t \right) \] where $ \boldsymbol{y}_n $ is the current value, $ \Delta t $ is the time step size, and $ f(\boldsymbol{y}) $ is the rate of change.

memberdef.argsstring: (Eigen::Matrix< double, ySize, 1 > yN, const double dt, const double TOL, functionType fRate, Args &&... fRateArgs)
memberdef.name: explicitEulerRichardsonWithErrorEstimator

briefdescription.para: Explicit Euler integration based on Richardson extrapolation with error estimation and time step estimation.

detaileddescription.para:
ySize
Size of the state vector
yType
Type of the current value
Args
Additional argument types for the rate function
functionType
Type of the rate function
Args
Additional argument types for the rate function
yN
Current value
dt
Current time step size
TOL
Desired tolerance for the error estimation
fRate
Function that computes the rate of change
fRateArgs
Additional arguments for the rate function
Tuple containing the updated value after time step and the new time step size
This function computes one single time step using the explicit Euler method with Richardson extrapolation for error estimation and adaptive time stepping: \[ \boldsymbol{y}_{n+1} = 2 \left( \boldsymbol{y}_n + f\left(\boldsymbol{y}_n + \frac{f(\boldsymbol{y}_n) \Delta t}{2}\right) \frac{\Delta t}{2} \right) - \left( \boldsymbol{y}_n + f(\boldsymbol{y}_n) \Delta t \right) \] where $ \boldsymbol{y}_n $ is the current value, $ \Delta t $ is the current time step size, and $ f(\boldsymbol{y}) $ is the rate of change.

The function also estimates the error of the time step and adjusts the time step size for the next iteration based on the desired tolerance TOL. The new time step size is computed as: \[ \Delta t_{\text{new}} = \Delta t \cdot \min\left(2, \max\left(0.2, 0.9 \sqrt{\frac{TOL}{EST}}\right)\right) \] where $ EST $ is the estimated error.

briefdescription.para: Computes the direction cosines between a given coordinate system and the global coordinate system.

detaileddescription.para:
transformedCoordinateSystem
3x3 matrix representing the transformed coordinate system
3x3 matrix of direction cosines
The direction cosines are computed as the dot products between the basis vectors of the transformed coordinate system and the global coordinate system.

briefdescription.para: Constructs a orthonormal coordinate system with a given normal vector as $x_1$-axis.

detaileddescription.para:
normalVector
Input normal vector, which will be normalized and used as $x_1$-axis.
Orthonormal coordinate system as a 3x3 matrix.
The orthonormal coordinate system is constructed such that:
The first column corresponds to the normalized input normal vector ( $x_1$-axis).
The second column is a unit vector orthogonal to the first ( $x_2$-axis).
The third column is the cross product of the first two columns ( $x_3$-axis).

simplesect.para: Do not use this function if you want to control the direction of the axes in the plane orthogonal to the normal vector.

xrefdescription.para: : Maybe remove this function completely to avoid mistakes?

briefdescription.para: Constructs an orthonormal coordinate system with two given normal vectors.

detaileddescription.para:
n1
First input vector.
n2
Second input vector.
Orthonormal coordinate system as a 3x3 matrix.
std::invalid_argument
if the input normal vectors are not orthogonal.
The orthonormal coordinate system is constructed such that:
The first column corresponds to the normalized first input normal vector ( $x_1$-axis).
The second colum corresponds to the normalized second input normal vector ( $x_2$-axis).
The third column is the normalized cross product of the first two columns ( $x_3$-axis).

briefdescription.para: Transforms a second-order tensor from the global coordinate system to a local coordinate system.

detaileddescription.para:
T
The tensor to be transformed, represented as a 3x3 matrix in the global coordinate system.
transformedCoordinateSystem
The 3x3 transformation matrix representing the local coordinate system axes in global coordinates.
The tensor represented in the local coordinate system as a 3x3 matrix.
The transformation is performed as: $ T_{local} = Q^T \, T_{global} \, Q $, where $ Q $ is the transformation matrix.

briefdescription.para: Transforms a second-order tensor from a local coordinate system to the global coordinate system.

detaileddescription.para:
T
The tensor to be transformed, represented as a 3x3 matrix in the local coordinate system.
transformedCoordinateSystem
The 3x3 transformation matrix representing the local coordinate system axes in global coordinates.
The tensor represented in the global coordinate system as a 3x3 matrix.
The transformation is performed as: $ T_{global} = Q \, T_{local} \, Q^T $, where $ Q $ is the transformation matrix.
